title: Capacitors - add a second block of dielectric

content.question: The figures show two different capacitors made of identical parallel conducting plates. In Capacitor <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the plates are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> and a block of material with dielectric constant <math alttext="kappa" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>κ</mi></math> is inserted between the plates. In Capacitor <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the plates are separated by a distance <math alttext="2 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></math> and two identical blocks of material with dielectric constant <math alttext="kappa" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>κ</mi></math> are inserted between the plates. A student claims that the capacitance of Capacitor <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is the same as that of Capacitor <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Which of the following indicates whether the claim is correct or incorrect, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: Correct, because the effects of doubling the distance between the plates and doubling the volume of the dielectric cancel each other.
Correct, because the capacitance is a property of the plates and the plates have not changed.
Incorrect, because doubling the thickness of the dielectric material will cause the capacitance to double.
Incorrect, because doubling the distance between the plates will reduce the capacitance by half.

content.answer: Incorrect, because doubling the distance between the plates will reduce the capacitance by half.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
